repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Additional Financing for the
            Sustainable Development of Natural Resources Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Additional Financing for
            the Sustainable Development of Natural Resources Project
            (SDNRP) for Afghanistan were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            high, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: strong regulatory compliance in
            oil, gas, and mining projects alone is not sufficient to
            achieve sustainability. Rather, there is need for inclusive
            growth that is measured by economic, environmental, and
            social performance. A large mining technical assistance
            should have the flexibility to take on broader environmental
            and social responsibilities if parallel activities are
            curtailed, especially in the situation of fragile, conflict
            states where environmental safeguards are not well
            established - as was the case in SDNRP. The extractive
            industries (EI) sector to lead to long-term sustainable
            inclusive growth in Afghanistan, the Bank will need to
            support a variety interventions through a programmatic
            approach which includes, traditional technical assistance to
            the Ministry of Mines and Petroleum (MoMP) (SDNRP one and
            two); a National Resource Corridor Project; finding creative
            tools to leverage financing and mitigate risk for associated
            EI infrastructure; and development policy lending including
            triggers related to the passage of the mining law (2013).
            Environmental and social safeguards must be given strong
            attention in a project providing technical assistance to the
            government to attract new investment. The presence of very
            experienced mining, social, and environmental specialists
            from the Bank, as well as frequent Bank supervision missions
            (every 6 - 10 weeks) proved to be crucial to the project
            responding effectively to meet new needs and challenges
            around the Aynak mineral deposit especially regarding
            environmental and social protection and introducing
            innovative concepts such as mineral resource corridors.
            There is a need for deep capacity-building within the
            project management unit (PMU) of procurement processes,
            procedures, and planning.

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Sustainable Development of
            Natural Resources Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Sustainable
            Development of Natural Resources Project for Afghanistan is
            to assist the recipient in improving Ministry of Mines'
            capacity to effectively regulate the mineral and hydrocarbon
            resources sector in a transparent manner, and to foster
            private sector development. The closing date for the project
            will be extended from December 31, 2012 until May 31, 2013.
            The major achievements under the project to date have
            included: 1) establishing a transparent and accountable in
            tender processes, highlighted by the successful Aynak and
            Hajigak transactions which was supported at all stages by
            the International Advisory Panel (IAP); 2) supporting the
            implementation of the Extractive Industries Transparency
            Initiative (EITI) and the complementary disclosure of
            mining-generated revenues; 3) increasing oversight and
            enforcement capacity of agencies such as the Mines
            Inspectorate and the National Environmental Protection
            Agency; 4) strengthening of the Ministry of Mines (MoM)
            departments responsible for cadastre and mine title
            management; and 5) supporting archeological activities and
            cultural preservation at Mes Aynak. The extension is
            necessary to allow the project to meet select core results
            indicators prior to closing. The MoM has drafted an action
            plan to meet those objectives and complete the project. This
            will be the second extension of the project. The first
            extension was for a period of 17 months, from the original
            closing date of July 31, 2011 to the current date of
            December 31, 2012.

display_title.display_title:
Afghanistan - Sustainable
            Development of Natural Resources Project : restructuring :
            Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Sustainable Development of
            Natural Resources Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Sustainable
            Development of Natural Resources Project for Afghanistan is
            to assist the recipient in improving Ministry of Mines'
            capacity to effectively regulate the mineral and hydrocarbon
            resources sector in a transparent manner, and to foster
            private sector development. The project has four components:
            1. improving Ministry of mines' internal efficiencies;
            2. developing regulatory capacity; 3. developing mineral
            resources; and 4. improving sector governance. The Ministry
            of mines has submitted an updated implementation action plan
            which takes into account some of the difficulties, primarily
            with regard to strengthening its procurement capacities. An
            improvement of disbursement rates is already visible since
            FY 2011. This will be the first extension of the project.
